metadata.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Associated Cement Companies Ltd. (A.C.C.), Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd. (C.M.I.), and Concrete Association of India (C.A.I.) faced demands for bonus from workmen employed in Bombay offices for 1953-54: seven months basic wages with dearness allowance for A.C.C., C.M.I., C.A.I.; 50% of total earnings or six months total earnings for Dwarka Cement Works.
Disputes referred to Industrial Tribunal, Bombay under s.10 Industrial Disputes Act: Ref. I.T. No. 10 of 1956 and I.T. No. 13 of 1956, heard together.
Tribunal awarded bonus equivalent to 1/3 of basic wages or pay less bonus already paid, subject to conditions, on November 30, 1956.
A.C.C. already paid three months basic wages bonus; C.M.I. same to its workmen; C.M.I. undertakes to pay same as A.C.C. employees.

C.M.I. is 100% subsidiary of A.C.C., registered separately; C.A.I. is department of C.M.I.; common staff in Bombay; financial transactions and assets integrated into A.C.C. accounts from August 1, 1953.

A.C.C. biggest cement manufacturer in India, owns 15 factories in India, 2 in Pakistan; despatched 55.46% of total cement in 1953-54; formed 1936 by merger of 11 companies from groups: E. Dinshaw, Tatas, Killick Nixon, Khatau.

Respondents alleged A.C.C. monopoly, inflated capital in 1936 merger, expanded using profits without fresh capital, capitalised premium-on-shares and reserves for taxation in 1953-54, inadequate emoluments entitling bonus to bridge living wage gap; prior rehabilitation claim included expansion.

Appellant denied monopoly, inflation of capital, use of profits for expansion; claimed high maintenance needs due to cement industry nature, favourable wages, need for >6% on paid-up capital, >4% on working capital; Ex. C-23 shows deficit; already paid 3 months bonus though no surplus.
Evidence: Mr. Tongaonkar (appellant), Ex. C-2 (replacement costs), Ex. C-10 (1936 assets), Ex. C-29 (capital expenditure 1936-54), Ex. C-23 (deficit calculation).

Tribunal framed 10 issues; found no capital inflation; allowed 6% on paid-up capital Rs.1267.59 lakhs, 4% on working capital; normal straight-line depreciation; income-tax at 83.4 pies/rupee; rejected excluding investment income; allowed gratuity Rs.10 lakhs, dismantling etc.; included overtime in bonus base; rejected Ex. C-2 as exaggerated.

Tribunal capped rehabilitation at Rs.192-193 lakhs based on prior claims/Tariff Commission, allowed Rs.165-170 lakhs; actual spend 1952-53/53-54 Rs.339.76 lakhs avg Rs.170 lakhs; reserves Rs.235+76 lakhs over 10 years Rs.31 lakhs deduction; surplus Rs.23.48 lakhs after 1 month additional bonus.
Previous adjudication Ref. I.T. No. 115 of 1953 for 1951-52 decided points against respondents.
Tariff Commission report April 1953: Rs.18.36 crores over 10 years from 1952-08-01, approx Rs.184 lakhs/year.
Prior proceedings Ex. U-8 (Jan 1954): Rs.192-193 lakhs/year rehabilitation.

legal_issues.text: Quantum of bonus for 1953-54 under Full Bench formula, particularly provision for rehabilitation, replacement, modernisation.
Whether tribunal can cap rehabilitation claim based on prior statements/estoppel.
Whether Full Bench formula needs revision/reconstruction.
Computation of depreciation: normal vs. including initial/additional.
Income-tax calculation: including concessions for initial/additional depreciation.
Return on paid-up capital and working capital rates.

petitioner_arguments.text: Points raised by respondents decided in prior Ref. I.T. No. 115/1953; cement industry needs high maintenance/rehabilitation due to heavy machinery running ceaselessly; no monopoly, aims cheap cement; no capital inflation in 1936; no profits used for expansion; wages favourable; calculations per formula show deficit (Ex. C-23); claim >6% paid-up, >4% working capital; already paid 3 months bonus though no surplus.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Full Bench formula (Mill Owners Association v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh)

petitioner_arguments.text: Prior Tariff Commission report and Ex. U-8 not exhaustive claims under formula; Ex. C-3 in prior case was formula claim ignored by tribunal.
Formula worked well for 8+ years, no departure; rigid application shows no surplus.

respondent_arguments.text: A.C.C. monopoly position enables payment; inflated 1936 capital; expansion from profits no fresh capital; 1953-54 capitalised premiums/reserves; inadequate wages need bonus for living wage gap; prior 1951-52 rehabilitation included expansion; no >4% on paid-up, 2% working capital; statements per Full Bench formula.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal erred in rejecting Ex. C-2/Tongaonkar evidence without own findings on life/divisors; no estoppel from prior modest claims as not formula-based; formula not rigid mathematical, elastic via objective scrutiny.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ex. C-2 not exaggerated; prior claims not binding.

court_reasoning.text: No revision of formula; worked satisfactorily; elastic for justice; prior charges: gross profits accepted unless mala fide; depreciation: notional normal (Surat Electricity); income-tax on balance including initial/additional depreciation concessions; return on capital variable per case (6% paid-up usual); rehabilitation block-wise, estimate life/replacement cost.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Formula based on labour share in profits and wage gap; year as self-sufficient unit.

court_reasoning.text: No special prior charge for wasting industry prospecting; buildings included in rehabilitation.

holdings.text: Full Bench formula not to be revised; to be applied elastically with objective scrutiny of evidence.
Tribunal erred in capping rehabilitation at Rs.192 lakhs based on estoppel/prior conduct; must assess per evidence.
Depreciation: notional normal depreciation per Surat Electricity Co.
Income-tax: calculated including s.10(2)(vi) concessions for initial/additional depreciation.
Return on capital: rates flexible per circumstances, ordinarily 6% paid-up, lower on working.
Rehabilitation: divide blocks, estimate life/replacement cost; block-wise for large industries.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held tribunal erred in arbitrarily capping rehabilitation provision and rejecting evidence without findings; affirmed Full Bench formula as elastic, not rigid; laid down principles for computing depreciation, tax, returns, rehabilitation; case implies remand for re-computation per principles.
outcome.relief_granted: Companies' appeal allowed in part on rehabilitation; principles for bonus formula.

key_quotes.text: "We must make it as flexible as possible so as to do justice to everybody concerned in the earning of profits."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Tribunal's view on formula flexibility, critiqued by Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "As both capital and labour contribute to the earnings of the industrial concern, it is fair that labour should derive some benefit if there is a surplus after meeting prior or necessary charges."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle of Full Bench formula affirmed.

key_quotes.text: "The formula is elastic enough to meet reasonably the claims of the industry and labour for fairplay and justice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Supreme Court's holding on formula's application.
